ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed skills involving complex analysis of texts both ancient and modern, as well as much writing practice. This class represented an interesting survey course of various historical and philosophical courses on the nature of free speech.

This was a great course to develop your writing skills. Professor Klein is super attentive to every response paper and really helps you engage with the material by responding to what you have written. He also lets you be very creative with the reading responses which allows you to articulate what you took from the readings in a way that is most interesting and fun for you. The final is also super flexible which allows you to write about something you are passionate about.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths of this course was the syllabus and the seminars. The syllabus was very thoughtfully organized, and all the readings made sense in creating a larger picture of the seminar. The seminars were interesting ways to discuss the topics at hand and Professor Klein always had interesting insights to make. Weaknesses included the Professor's online handwriting being hard to read for feedback.

Strengths are that the selections of readings are really interesting and the freedom you have with the reading responses and finals boosts engagement. Weaknesses are that the seminar discussions are not structured and sometimes unorganized.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that the length of the seminar discussion could be shortened, or it could be more structured. However, the freedom to be creative made the course more engaging.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to any student who is willing and eager to read a lot and write a lot about the subject of free speech. However, Professor Klein is incredibly generous with the assignments.

I would recommend this class. Professor Klein is very knowledgeable about the subjects that he teaches. He really wants to hear what you have to think about the readings, and so the weekly discussions are very interesting. I learned a lot in this class, and I'm glad I took it.
I would recommend this course to anyone who enjoys being creative with writing and engaging with historical and philosophical texts.
